sa11:1.2: '\'"\\\'One time, the Buddha was staying at Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park in Jeta’s Grove of Śrāvastī. \\\'"\''
sa11:2.1: '\'"\\\'It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks, \\\'"\''
sa11:2.3: '\'"\\\'Whatever causes and conditions give rise to forms, they are also impermanent. \\\'"\''
sa11:2.4: '\'"\\\'How could forms that arise impermanent causes and impermanent conditions be permanent? \\\'"\''
sa11:2.5: '\'"\\\'Thus, feeling … perception … volition … consciousness is impermanent. \\\'"\''
sa11:2.6: '\'"\\\'Whatever causes and conditions give rise to consciousnesses, they are also impermanent. \\\'"\''
sa11:2.7: '\'"\\\'How could consciousnesses that arise from impermanent causes and impermanent conditions be permanent? \\\'"\''
sa11:2.8: '\'"\\\'“Thus, monks, form is impermanent, and feeling … perception … volition … consciousness is impermanent. \\\'"\''
sa11:2.9: '\'"\\\'What’s impermanent then is painful, what’s painful is not self, and what’s not self doesn’t belong to self. \\\'"\''
sa11:3.1: '\'"\\\'“Noble disciples who thus observe become disillusioned with form, and they become disillusioned with feeling … perception … volition … consciousness. \\\'"\''
sa11:3.5: '\'"\\\'‘My births have been ended, the religious practice has been established, and the task has been accomplished. \\\'"\''
sa11:3.6: '\'"\\\'I myself know that I won’t be subject to a later existence.’” \\\'"\''
sa11:4.1: '\'"\\\'When the monks heard what the Buddha taught, they rejoiced and approved. \\\'"\''
